citations.narrative:
The outdoor, primary enclosures housing 12 rabbits each have excessive accumulations of feces, old hay and organic
debris piling up on the pull-out trays under the wire floors of the enclosures. Accumulations of excreta and other organic
waste in primary enclosures can allow for the spread of disease hazards, create unpleasant odors, and attract pests.
Primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs, and other debris by periodic cleaning.
Correct by 04/21/2025.

The outdoor shelter structure for the rabbits was in need of general cleaning and housekeeping. The majority of the floor
space was covered with loose straw along with some rabbit fecal pellets, wild bird droppings and feathers, and
accumulated dust and debris. Additionally, there were miscellaneous items kept in the structure including old, dusty
furniture items, dirty storage bins, and an open bag of wood shavings.
Regular and effective cleaning/housekeeping is necessary to prevent the harborage of pests and to reduce the potential
for spread of disease. The premises must be kept clean and in good repair in order to facilitate the required husbandry
practices and to protect the health and well-being of the animals.
Correct by 04/28/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.56(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
The outdoor, primary enclosures housing 12 rabbits each have excessive accumulations of feces, old hay and organic 
debris piling up on the pull-out trays under the wire floors of the enclosures. Accumulations of excreta and other organic 
waste in primary enclosures can allow for the spread of disease hazards, create unpleasant odors, and attract pests. 
Primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs, and other debris by periodic cleaning. 
 
Correct by 04/21/2025. 
3.56(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The outdoor shelter structure for the rabbits was in need of general cleaning and housekeeping. The majority of the floor 
space was covered with loose straw along with some rabbit fecal pellets, wild bird droppings and feathers, and 
accumulated dust and debris. Additionally, there were miscellaneous items kept in the structure including old, dusty 
furniture items, dirty storage bins, and an open bag of wood shavings.  
 
Regular and effective cleaning/housekeeping is necessary to prevent the harborage of pests and to reduce the potential 
for spread of disease. The premises must be kept clean and in good repair in order to facilitate the required husbandry 
practices and to protect the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
Correct by 04/28/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
